chapterTitle: Return, Risk, and The Security Market Line

columns.text: In this exercise, we assess the portfolio returns and deviations.

The **expected return** is the net income or loss that an investor predicts on investments given known interest rates.

The **variance** of investment's return quantifies how each amount in the series of investments deviates from average and consequently from another value in the group.

The **standard deviation** is a statistical measure of the distribution of values around the mean of a population. This is the variance's square root.

Let's first identify the given amounts in the problem: 


| | Amount$\hspace{5pt}$| 
|:--|--:| 
|Boom: ||
|Probability return | 25% | 
|Stock A's rate of return |21%|
|Stock B's rate of return |33%|
|Stock C's rate of return |55%|
|Normal: ||
|Probability return |60%|
|Stock A's rate of return |17%|
|Stock B's rate of return |11%|
|Stock C's rate of return | 9%|
|Bust: ||
|Probability return | 15%| 
|Stock A's rate of return|0%|
|Stock B's rate of return |-21%|
|Stock C's rate of return |-45%|

## A. 

First, let us compute the expected return of each state of the economy. This is calculated by multiplying the given percentages by the stock's rate of return. Let us first compute the expected return during Boom. 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Expected return, Boom}&= {\text{(40\% $\times$ 21\%) + (40\% $\times$ 33\%) + (20\% $\times$ 55\%)}}\\
&={\text{8.40\% + 13.20\% + 11\%}}\\
&= {\textbf{32.60\%}}
\end{aligned}$$

**The expected return during Boom is 32.60%.**

Then, we also need to compute the expected return during normal state of economy. This is computed as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Expected return, Normal}&= {\text{(40\% $\times$ 17\%) + (40\% $\times$ 11\%) + (20\% $\times$ 9\%)}}\\
&={\text{6.80\%  + 4.40\% + 1.80\%}}\\
&= {\textbf{13\%}}
\end{aligned}$$

**The expected return during a normal state of the economy is 13%.**

Next, let us compute the expected return during bust state of economy. This is computed as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Expected return, Bust}&= {\text{(40\% $\times$ 0\%) + (40\% $\times$ -21\%) + (20\% $\times$ -45\%)}}\\
&={\text{ -8.40\% - 9\%}}\\
&= {\textbf{-17.40\%}}
\end{aligned}$$

**The expected return during a bust state of the economy is -17.40%.**

Since, we have already determined each expected return of the state of the economy, let us now compute the expected return of the portfolio. This is computed as follows: 

$$\begin{array}{l}
\text{Portfolio expected return}={\sum_\text{}}{\text{(Probability return $\times$ Expected return)}}\\
\hspace{110pt}={\text{(25\% $\times$ 32.60\%) + (60\% $\times$ 13\%)}}\\[5pt]
\hspace{120pt} + {\text{(15\% $\times$ -17.40\%)}} \\[5pt]
\hspace{110pt}={\text{8.15\% + 7.80\% - 2.61\%}}\\[5pt]
\hspace{110pt}= {\textbf{13.34\%}}
\end{array}$$

**The portfolio expected return is 13.34%.**

The variance of the stock's return is computed as follows: 


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{V}&={\sum_\text{}} {\text{PR $\times$(R - AR)}^\text{ 2}}
\end{aligned}$$

Where: \
PR = Probability return\
T = Year\
R = Realized return \
V = Variance

Let us compute the variance of the poprtfolio using the formula from step 8. This is computed as follows: 

$$\begin{array}{l}
\text{V}=  {\text{[25\% $\times$ (32.60\% - 13.34\%)}^\text{ 2}}{{]}} + {\text{[60\% $\times$ (13\% - 13.34\%)}^\text{ 2}}{{]}}\\[5pt]
\hspace{20pt} {\text{+ [15\% $\times$ (-17.40\% - 13.34\%)}^\text{ 2}}{{]}}\\
\hspace{10pt}= {\textbf{0.02345484}}
\end{array}$$

**The variance of the portfolio is 0.02345484.**

## B. 

A risk premium is an additional yield on investment above the risk-free rate of return. This is calculated by subtracting the projected return from the risk-free rate.

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Expected risk premium }&= {\text{ Portfolio expected return - Risk-free rate}}\\
&= {\text{ 13.34\% - 3.80\%}}\\
&= {\textbf{9.54\%}}
\end{aligned}$$


**The expected risk premium on the portfolio is 9.54%.**

## C. 

First, let us determine the approximate and exact expected real returns on the portfolio. Let us determine the approximate real return by using the formula from step 11. This is computed as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Expected risk premium }&= {\text{ Portfolio expected return - Risk-free rate}}\\
&= {\text{ 13.34\% - 3.30\%}}\\
&= {\textbf{10.04\%}}
\end{aligned}$$

**The expected risk premium considering the inflation is 10.04%.**

Next, let us determine the exact expected real returns on the portfolio. For this case, we will use a Fisher effect since the problem wants us to determine the relationship between nominal rates, real rates, and inflation. The Fisher effect is shown as follows: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{1 + PER }&= {\text{ (1 + ER) $\times$ (1 + h)}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Where: \
PER = Portfolio expected return \
ER = Expected return 
h = Inflaiton rate

Now, let us insert the data provided in this problem in the Fisher effect we have identified in the previous step. As an illustration, here's what it looks like: 

$$\begin{aligned}
\text{1 + 13.34\%}&= {\text{ (1 + ER) $\times$ (1 + 3.30\%)}}\\
\end{aligned}$$

Then, let us rearrange the formula by shifting the expected return to other side. This is computed as follows: 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{1 + ER}&= \dfrac{\text{ 1.1334}}{\text{1.0330}}\\
\text{ ER}&= {\text{ 1.10 - 1}}\\
\text{ ER}&= {\textbf{ 10\%}}\\
\end{aligned}$$
**The exact expected real returns on the portfolio is 10%.**

Next, let us determine the exact real risk premium on the portfolio. We will use the approximate expected real risk premium, which we have already computed in step 11. This is computed  as follows: 


$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Exact expected real risk premium}&= \dfrac{\text{ Approximate expected real risk premium}}{\text{1 + Inflation rate}}\\
&= \dfrac{\text{ 9.54\%}}{\text{1 + 3.3\%}}\\
&= {\textbf{9.23\%}}\\

\end{aligned}$$

**The exact expected real risk premium on the portfolio is 9.23%.**
